EXPERIENCE.Designation: Research Assistant - Gatsby Computational Neuroscience Unit
Research Assistant - Center for Formal Design and Verification of Software Lab

COURSES COMPLETED.Name: Speech and Natural Language Processing and the Web

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: GameSAT - A structured approach to combine SLS SAT-solvers
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description:
We designed and implemented an algorithm in the UBCSAT framework that tries to find models for
SAT using automated combination of multiple SLS SAT-solvers in a competitive way

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: M.Tech Thesis - Local Search In Approximate Submodular Maximization and Usage In Diverse Feature Selection
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description: I developed a faster algorithmic approach, with rigorous mathematical proofs, that promised similar optimality guarantee at a much lower cost compared to the alternatives taken in the existing literature for solving the class of optimization problems that arise in the context.

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: Bachelor's Thesis - InstAndroid - A Real-time Android Media Surfer
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description:
• We developed a media player for Android phones with predictive instant search on local media
• We also designed a simple heuristic that ranks the search results as per user’s current-most-favorite item

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: Google Summer of Code - Testing and Measuring Variable Interactions With Kernels
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description:
• I aimed at showcasing several kernel-based statistical hypothesis testing approaches under one modular framework along with demonstration and exploring further research opportunity.
• I also designed and developed Shogun's feature selection framework.

PROJECTS TAKEN.Title of Project: Google Summer of Code - Implement estimators of large-scale sparse Gaussian densities
PROJECTS TAKEN.Description: I developed a framework for an open source machine learning toolbox, Shogun, that approximates log-determinant of linear operators up to a high precision using techniques described in Aune et. al. (2008), while targeting for linear speedup by enabling parallel computation of the components involved.
